Title: Inference in Microeconometric Models

This project aims to develop innovative inference methods for microeconometric models that account for unobserved heterogeneity by leveraging longitudinal data. The proposed research is divided into three interconnected blocks. The first block focuses on enhancing the performance of statistical hypothesis tests in nonlinear models, while the second block develops formal results for estimating models using network data as panel data. The third block concentrates on non-parametric estimation of dynamic discrete-choice models, incorporating unobserved type heterogeneity and latent state variables.

The proposed methods will have significant applications in understanding labor force participation and the import and export behavior of firms and countries. Theoretical and simulation-based assessments will be employed to evaluate the performance of the developed methods. The underlying motivation for this research is the recognition that unobserved differences between economic agents drive differences in economic outcomes, such as schooling decisions, wages, and employment durations. By developing robust inference methods that account for these differences, this project will provide researchers and policymakers with more accurate tools to analyze and inform economic policy decisions. The expected outcomes of this project will contribute to a deeper understanding of microeconomic phenomena, ultimately leading to more effective policy interventions and improved economic outcomes.
